headlines.headline: Murray sends GB through after five-set win over Nishikori
Czech Republic will host France after Rosol beats Zverev
Mayer secures winning rubber, Argentina travel to Italy next
Croatia earn USA trip after Coric wins Liege decider
Serbia beat Kazakhstan 3-2, will host GB next

blogs.blog:
Hello and welcome back to the Live Blog as we cover round one of the Davis Cup by BNP Paribas. Hope you're ready for another cracking day of tennis. First up we turn our sights to Kooyong in Melbourne, Australia for the reverse singles rubbers. Here’s the order of play…

 

1. Bernard Tomic (AUS) v John Isner (USA)

 

Followed by 

 

2. Sam Groth (AUS) v Jack Sock (USA)

For those who are cheering on their team from home in Australia, you can watch live on Channel 7 while for USA fans can watch all the action on the Tennis Channel and of course, as always there is also our live stream on DavisCup.tv

Today's reverse singles at Kooyong are a couple of minutes away and intrigue regarding the Aussie line-up continues. For the hosts, all rests on the shoulders of Bernard Tomic. If the No.1 Aussie can again overcome an opponent he has never before beaten in John Isner, and extend the tie to a fifth rubber, there's a more than even chance Lleyton Hewitt will take the court for the decider, in place of the out-of-form Sam Groth. The Aussie captain has a win over Jack Sock on grass and beat the American No.2 at the Hopman Cup just weeks ago, when they shared a sporting moment. Not least, it was Hewitt who clinched the tie for Australia against Kazakhstan last July in Darwin, on home turf.

Following the Bryans’ doubles win for the USA yesterday, Australia’s hopes will lie with Tomic to keep the tie alive. Grab a cup of your favourite hot beverage and sit tight with us as we cover all the action here on the Live Blog.
Off to a flying start, both players are holding serve and still finding their groove. We could be in for a close one!
First blood to the USA. A few stray shots into the net from Tomic and a sweeping cross court drop-shot from Isner seals the break.

#Tomic lost to #Isner, at Delray Beach 2012, in their last match; can BT reverse that trend in @DavisCup? #AUSUSA pic.twitter.com/TpZxyabtSP

— AusTennisMag (@AusTennisMag) March 6, 2016
It's a beautiful sunny day in Melbourne and the packed out crowd (trombones and saxaphones included!) at Kooyong is right behind Tomic as he holds serve. Isner will serve for the first set.
Isner powers through with a typically strong service game to seal the first set 64.
Isner's service game continues to perplex Tomic. At 6'10 the American's serve is getting some considerable bounce on the Kooyong grass.

@DavisCup Tomic in the fourth rubber against @JohnIsner #mustwin #AUSUSA #GoAussies pic.twitter.com/5aYhwf7QM5

— John Diano (@John_JackDiego) March 6, 2016

A unforced error into the net by Tomic allows Isner to finally clinch the break point (the fourth of the game). Tomic is standing way back behind the baseline allowing Isner to play some tactical tennis.
Tomic has just taken a quick medical time-out to receive treatment on his wrist.

.@DylanAlcott and girlfriend Kate cheering on Bernie #Tomic at Kooyong. #GoAussies #AUSUSA pic.twitter.com/qYGwDjqKlS

— TennisAustralia (@TennisAustralia) March 6, 2016

Australia in trouble as Isner takes the second set for the USA, 64. A reminder that Tomic must win this match to keep the tie alive for the Green & Gold. Tomic's wrist seems to be giving him some trouble at the moment and he's struggling to find rhythm.

blog.tle: Captain Hewitt lends Tomic some words of encouragement

blogs.blog: Tomic and Isner both holding serve so far in the third set. Isner remains cool as a cucumber and is taking command of the situation with some aggressive tennis.
As usual, Isner's serve is proving to be the strong point of this match. He's slamed down 23 aces so far compared to Tomic's 8.
Tomic continues to hold serve. Do we smell a tiebreak?
Intense moment for the Aussies. Tomic brings up his third set point and the crowd are going bonkers!
This game has been going for 9 minutes now! Both Tomic and Isner are struggling to convert the game point.
Tomic has done it! He gets the break and takes the third set 75 and keeps the tie alive for now. Things aren't over just yet for the Australians. Could there be a Hewitt-esque comeback in the works?

The end to that third set was crazy! So happy Tomic won it. 😀 #GoAussies #AUSUSA #DavisCup

— Cassie (@coolcassie) March 6, 2016
A spark seems to have ignited in Tomic. He powers through his second love game of the fourth set. Isners game is waning.

Isner hit 253 km/h (157.2) on a serve in third set according to radar gun...would be fastest serve ever above challenger level. #DavisCup

— Ben Rothenberg (@BenRothenberg) March 6, 2016

Experiencing a bit of déjà vu here in the fourth set. Both players continuing to hold serve in very quick games as we head into the critical part of the set. Will Bernard break to take the match into a fifth and deciding set? Stay with us to find out!
This match is evolving into quite the nail-biter. Isner holds to take the fourth set into a tie-break.
A sweeping cross-court forehand followed by an ace help Isner even the tie-break at 3-3.

.@JohnIsner will be looking to put the U.S. into the QFs for the 1st time since 2013 today. Let's go John #USATennis pic.twitter.com/d9oUTbjvAm

— US Davis Cup Team (@USDavisCupTeam) March 5, 2016

In true style, Isner finishes the match with his 49th ace to take the match and the tie for the USA. Final score 64 64 57 76(4). 

The USA will now host the winner of Croatia v Belgium in the quarterfinals.

blog.tle: Isner seals Round One victory for USA

blogs.blog: Our team prepared very well, I think it showed out here. It was an incredible tie for us, Australia put up a great fight. We knew this match was going to be very, very tough. It was such an honour for us to play here at Kooyong, this is a beautiful place and the fans are awesome. So thank you.

Congratulations to the @USDavisCupTeam. That was a great tie, good luck in your next one. #GoAussies #AUSUSA pic.twitter.com/2Aqtpy6w4o

— TennisAustralia (@TennisAustralia) March 6, 2016

Stars & Stripes prevail in Davis Cup!!! #GoUSATENNIS #DAVISCUP

— Janine Salmon (@RPImom) March 6, 2016
Team USA pose for photos following their 3-1 round one win over Australia. This was the USA's 285th Davis Cup by BNP Paribas tie, the most of any nation.

Jim Courier: 'it was a tough match up on paper and a tough match up in reality.' #AUSUSA pic.twitter.com/rFRF3d6F5a

— TennisAustralia (@TennisAustralia) March 6, 2016

Well that concludes our coverage at Kooyong. Congratulations again to team USA! Our Davis Cup by BNP Paribas World Group coverage will kick off again in around 7 hours beginning with Poland v Argentina live from 1100 GMT where Poland will be fighting to keep the tie alive in the reverse singles. 

 

See you soon!

Welcome back to the blog. Thank you for joining us. The USA, Italy and France are all through to July's quarterfinals but who will join them?  Let's go forth into Sunday's Davis Cup by BNP Paribas finale and find out!

Our man courtside has news from the first of the remaining World Group first-round matches between Poland and Argentina...

 

"Gday from Gdansk. No changes from either team captain ahead of the fourth rubber here in northern Poland. Argentina look to their No.1 Leo Mayer to wrap up victory and book a quarterfinal date against Italy. The world No.41 is going for his 11th successive Davis Cup match win. Poland are hoping their No.1 Michal Przysiezny can produce the shock of the weekend. The recently-injured world No.318 played his first match for three months on Friday when he lost in straight sets to Guido Pella. It’s a tall order, but you never know..."

Do you want to follow this action this #DavisCup weekend but don't know how? Here's a handy guide! pic.twitter.com/QAVDMxlBX8

— Davis Cup (@DavisCup) March 6, 2016

So it's time to settle down for our first live tie. For those in Poland please tune your TVs to TVP while for fans in Poland it's on TyC Sport. For everyone else, please join us on the daviscup.tv live streaming sofa.

A little progress report from Gdansk. Some quick service games from Leonardo Mayer keep us on serve so far in this crucial fourth rubber between Poland and Italy. Mayer has only lost a single point so far in those three games by the way. Tough task for Michal Przysiezny, who is aiming to extend Poland's first-ever foray in the World Group.
Watching courtside in Poland is this furry fella. Say hello to the mascot. It's a giant tennis ball on legs right?

blog.tle: Coming soon... Germany v Czech Republic

blogs.blog: Some big matches coming your way very soon. In Hannover, Philipp Kohlschreiber must beat Tomas Berdych to keep alive Germany's hopes against the formidable Czech Republic Davis Cup machine. On paper Berdych has an 8-1 head-to-head record over Kohlschreiber, who last beat him in 2009. Maybe he can channel his inner Cher and turn back time?

Congrats to @JohnIsner @JackSock @Bryanbros @Bryanbrothers on the win. Thanks to Melbourne for being a great host! pic.twitter.com/JYuWeKpl97

— US Davis Cup Team (@USDavisCupTeam) March 6, 2016

blog.tle: Get ready for the World No.1...

blogs.blog: Novak Djokovic reckoned he was a bit rusty on the doubles court on Saturday, missing volleys and getting his movement muddled. The Belgrade crowd will expect the usually well-oiled tennis machine to take to the court against Mikhail Kukushkin and level the tie for Serbia against Kazakhstan. The players have only met once before, in fact, with Djokovic winning that encounter at the 2014 Shanghai Masters.
Well, over in Poland this tight first set between Michal Przysiezny and Leonardo Mayer will be decided in the tiebreak.

Czech Republic head into today's action in Hannover as the firm favourites to reach the quarterfinal. The two No. 1s - Tomas Berdych and Philipp Kohlschreiber - face off in the first of the reverse singles and their head-to-head record will give German fans a slight sinking feeling. Berdych has won eight of his previous nine meetings with Kohlschreiber so it will take something special from the German if he is to force a fifth rubber. The task is a daunting one but Kohlschreiber does have 21 top-10 wins to his name so let's not rule anything out just yet. After all, this is Davis Cup...

There was little to choose between Argentina's Leo Mayer and Poland's Michael Przysiezny in the opening set in Gdansk. It came down to one crucial moment in the tiebreak when Mayer failed to put away an overhead and then netted a backhand volley. A pair of big serves from the Pole seal the breaker 7-4 and that's the set. Mayer had more winners and less unforced errors in that opening set but that's not how things roll in the Davis Cup…

DavisCup.com's Lee Goodall: "Wow. All credit to Michal Przysiezny who takes the first set breaker 7-4 off Mayer. Wrap your head around this stat: Mayer dropped just TWO points on serve in that opener and he lost the set! The turning point came when Przysiezny hustled back a Mayer overhead at 4-4 in the shootout only for the Argentine to fluff a low backhand volley. That gave Przysiezny a 5-4 advantage and he nervelessly served out the next two points. It’ll be VERY interesting to see how Mayer reacts to the disappointment. He’s played great but has nothing to show for it. The Poles are excited inside the Ergo Arena..."
It's time to tune into Belgrade. For Serbia fans please switch channels to RTS while for Kazakhstan fans it's KazSport. For everyone else, please join us on the happy daviscup.tv live streaming sofa.

If, unlike Sascha Zverev or Radek Stepanek, you can't eagerly, and anxiously, watch Germany v Czech Republic from the side of the court please tune those TVs to Prosieben Sat1 Gold or Czech TV. For everyone else, we still have spare seats on the daviscup.tv live streaming sofa.

#GBRJPN It will be @andy_murray v @keinishikori in the opening match today in Birmingham! Who are you supporting? pic.twitter.com/G368AVSlmc

— Davis Cup (@DavisCup) March 6, 2016

DavisCup.com's Lee Goodall has an update: "Michal Przysiezny shouldn't underestimate his opponent's staying power today. This time last year remember, Leo Mayer won the second longest match of all time - and the longest Davis Cup singles match - when he beat Brazilian Joao Souza 7-6 (4), 7-6 (5), 5-7, 5-7, 15-13. That one lasted six hours and 42 minutes. I'm going to start carbo-loading on Polish deserts just to be on the safe side…"

A really good atmosphere bubbling in Belgrade as Novak Djokovic and Mikhail Kukushkin size each other up. The Kazakh clenches his first as he holds his opening service game, while Novak Djokovic has his game face on, his aim to level the tie for Serbia.

Seated, ready & waiting to cheer on #TeamGB! Bring. It. On. @DavisCup @BritishTennis #BackTheBrits 🎾🏆

— Helen (@ConinaUK) March 6, 2016

Over in Hannover, things seems a little more sedate in the opening exchanges between Philipp Kohlschreiber and Tomas Berdych. A tough job for the German who is trying to level the tie for the home side against the 2012 and 2013 Czech champions.

Just a quick peek over the fence in Bangkok, where Thailand have tied up victory against Sri Lanka in Asia/Oceania World Group II. It went down to the fifth rubber where Pruchya Isarow came through 64 67(5) 63 76(6) against Harshanna Godamanna to book the Thais' place in July's second round. Congratulations!

Concern for the Czech team. Tomas Berdych has just the left court in Hannover for a medical timeout. The world No.7 was indicating he might have a problem with his left upper thigh. He's just been broken by Philipp Kohlschreiber too in the opening set.

An interesting start here in the TUI Arena as Kohlschreiber secures the first break of the match to go 3-2 up. The German is looking much sharper than he did in Friday's scratchy win over Lukas Rosol. I'll be honest, I didn't see that break coming. Kohlschreiber spent the first two games on Berdych's serve looping returns down the centre of the court, right into the Czech's hitting zone, but in that game he stepped up. A roaring forehand return winner at deuce gave him a second break point and he duly converted.
Lots happening in Davis Cup by BNP Paribas around the world but here's something we've seen before, it's another tiebreak to settle the second set between Michal Przysiezny and Leo Mayer. Stand by.

Leo Mayer finds himself right in the zone and pummelling Poland's Michal Przysiezny with some tasty forehands for a 5-2 lead in the tiebreak. The Argentina is pretty pumped after firing over an ace to win the breaker 74 and level the match. On we go...

Mayer edges another serve-dominated set - no man has had a single break point from 24 service games so far. Przysiezny dug himself a hole when he missed a backhand volley on the opening point of the breaker to give Mayer an immediate advantage and back-to-back aces made it 3-0. Try as he might, Przysiezny couldn't get back on level terms and Mayer closed it out 7-4 with an ace up the ‘T’. Game on.

There's been some really great tennis between Novak Djokovic and Mikhail Kukushkin in Belgrade. Djokovic looped over a lovely lob to reach break point but the Kazakh fended that off and we're still on serve.
Fans of Tomas Berdych, you'll be eager to know that your man is now back on court. He is still a break down to Philipp Kohlschreiber in the first set in Hannover, however.

The DJ – who is standing on court on the baseline with his digital decks – is warming up the crowd in Birmingham. It's like Saturday night all over again.

 

Big match here this afternoon between two stars of the sport, Andy Murray and Kei Nishikori. It’s actually the first time, though, that Murray has faced a top-10 player in Davis Cup.

 

Murray has never lost a Davis Cup singles rubber on a hard court, he is currently 12-0. Nishikori is currently on an 11-match Davis Cup singles winning streak. Something has to give.

 

Here at Blog HQ we'd like to hear more about Stuart's Saturday night in Birmingham...

It goes without typing that there's plenty of support for Novak Djokovic in Serbia but our reporter Zoran Milosavljevic spotted this flag from Bulgarian fans showing their colours for the popular world No.1.

Finally we have a break of serve in Gdansk! And it's gone the way of Leo Mayer, who is finding his groove now for Argentina. If Mayer wins this match against Michal Przysiezny then Argentina will go through to meet Italy in the quarterfinals of the Davis Cup by BNP Paribas.

OK, now it starts getting busy. We have simultaneous kick-offs in Birmingham and Liege - Andy Murray v Kei Nishikori, or if that somehow doesn't tickle your fancy David Goffin v Marin Cilic.

 

BBC, Eurosport and Wowow are all covering the GB-Japan tie, with RTBF, VRT and HRT broadcasting the action in Liege. Alternatively, you can watch both rubbers through our live streaming service.

A big service hold from Novak Djokovic in Belgrade. He fights off a break point chance with a powerful drive-volley which Mikhail Kukushkin flies into the net. Djokovic roars as he moves to within one game of the opening set. It's really been tantalising tennis. Have we said that already?

German hopes remain alive in Hannover as Philipp Kohlschreiber wins the first set against Tomas Berdych, who had an injury timeout after going a break down. Kohlschreiber needs to win this match to keep Germany in the tie against the Czech Republic, lest we forget.

Leo Mayer is a step closer to victory in Gdansk as he closes out the second set in just 29 minutes. Michal Przysiezny, who has battled brilliantly here for Poland, sent down a double fault on set point.

Murray-Nishikori is arguably the most high profile individual clash this weekend, bringing together as it does two players ranked inside the top six in the world. Murray holds a 5-1 record over his Japanese adversary, the Scotsman's only defeat coming at the ATP World Tour Finals in 2014. Intriguingly, all six of those clashes have been won in straight sets.

From our reporter Clive White: Weary or not, David Goffin has begun the onerous task of keeping last year's runners-up in contention in this Davis Cup World Group first round tie in Liege against Croatia's Marin Cilic, who unlike the Belgian was able to put his feet up on Saturday. An encouraging start from the Belgian No 1 as he breaks the world No 12 in the opening game with a forehand winner. Somewhat surprisingly, these two have never met before.


Update: Cilic has immediately broken back...

In hindsight, maybe that missed Michal Przysiezny backhand volley at the start of the second set breaker turned the match? The margins are that fine at this level. The first break of the day finally went to Leo Mayer in the second game of the third set. The Argentine converted his third break point with a ripper of a cross-court forehand to go up 2-0. Mayer maintained that advantage - he's still only dropped a measly seven points on serve in three sets - and Przysiezny buckled again when serving to stay in the set at 2-5, Mayer’s second break of the match coming courtesy of a double fault on set point. Argentina now a set away from a quarterfinal trip to Italy...

We're with serve in the early stages of this match. A lovely crosscourt winner from Nishikori as he gets himself a solitary point in Murray's second service game. He'll need to string together a few of those to break the in-form Briton.

Oh, is that not just the most adorable sight of the week? This little fan is watching Goffin v Cilic, where the player she is supporting, Goffin, holds a 3-1 lead, Cilic having been broken twice in Liege.

Well, well, well what a fascinating opening set we've just witnessed in Belgrade. After six service holds apiece, Mikhail Kukushkin muscles his way through the tiebreak 86. On the other side of the net, Novak Djokovic flares his eyes and then troops back to his seat. The world No.1 has to win this match to level the tie for Serbia against Kazakhstan.

@DavisCup, what a beauty! Well done, Misha! 🇰🇿🎾

— Багыжан (@abubagyzhan) March 6, 2016

And there's the first break of the match in Birmingham. To the delight of the home crowd it's gone to their man. Murray returns well to bring up 15-40 on the Nishikori serve. The Japanese saves the first break point with a good serve, but then hits a weak groundstroke into the net.

Is a sensation on the cards in the Aleksandar Nikolic Arena!? Mikhail Kukushkin produced a flawless performance to win an absorbing first set against home crowd favourite Novak Djokovic 76 and bring Kazakhstan, who are 2-1 ahead in the tie, a step closer to stunning the 2010 Davis Cup winners. A jam-packed arena is also producing an exhilarating contest between rivals fans, both charged with drums and trumpets. While Kukushkin was at his best, a weary-looking Djokovic committed four double faults and a flurry of unforced errors.

DavisCup.com's Clive White in Liege reports...


Goffin has definitely settled the better in Liege and is tending to win the more extended rallies. Too many mistakes in Cilic's game at the moment. The Belgian is still one break up at 43.

Back to Germany, where the second set between Philipp Kohlschreiber and Tomas Berdych is poised on serve. The Hannover home fans are on their feet, tooting horns and clapping as they urge on their man, who must win this match to level the tie for Germany. Berdych, who beat Kolschreiber in the doubles yesterday, is looking a bit tired but he is also keen on adding to his 50 Davis Cup wins.

Argentina are through to the Davis Cup by BNP Paribas quarterfinals where they will travel to meet Italy. It's all thanks to Leonardo Mayer who turned up the heat to come through a 67(4) 76 (4)62 63 winner against Michal Przysiezny. The result means Poland's debut in the World Group comes to a premature end and they must work their way through the World Group play-offs in July.
Aha, game on in Birmingham as a rasping winning return from Kei Nishikori allows him to break back against Andy Murray - that point met with a resounding silence from inside the arena...
Stats fans might like to have a look at the full facts and figures for Leo Mayer's win against Michal Przysiezny.

First set safely pocketed by David Goffin, who frankly seems to have Marin Cilic in his pocket at the moment. The Croatian is hitting some awfully wild shots at the moment, indoor clay not his thing perhaps.

More drama in Germany, Tomas Berdych has retired from his match against Philipp Kohlschreiber after losing the second set 75. The world No.7 had a medical timeout after being broken in the opening set, which he lost 63, for a thigh injury and he did look like he was struggling. That means we will go to a deciding fifth rubber in Hannover. Well, why have four rubbers when you can have five?!

ARGENTINA WINS!! @YacaMayer d. Przysiezny 67(4) 76(4) 62 63 to send Argentina through to the #DavisCup quarterfinals pic.twitter.com/LeVRtdNHfD

— Davis Cup (@DavisCup) March 6, 2016

Wow. This is quite something. We are level at 2-2 here in Hannover as Tomas Berdych pulls the plug after dropping the second set to Philipp Kohlschreiber. Berdych went off court after the fifth game of the first set for some treatment on his leg and he returned with his right thigh heavily strapped. He clearly couldn't carry on anymore, but credit must go to the German who played extremely well today. Now for a decisive fifth rubber, which will see Sascha Zverev take on Lukas Rosol. Both captains do have the option to change their nominations - could we see Radek Stepanek summoned? Let's see...

There's another break for Goffin at the top of the second set, Cilic still struggling to land his first serve and still struggling to back up his second serves with decent tennis - far too many unforced errors from the big Croat's racket so far.


Here's Clive White: "Rather than looking worn out on a third consecutive day on court, Goffin looks more in the groove than Cilic. The big difference is second serve - Cilic's is being dealt with severely. He has won only 33% of second serve points compared to the Belgian's 68%."
A fascinating match continues in Belgrade. Novak Djokovic and Mikhail Kukushkin have swapped breaks in the second set and it's so, so close.

We could be closing on a tiebreak in the first set of the day in Birmingham. Both players looking fairly comfortable in the conditions, probably Murray finding it marginally easier to hold than his opponent.

Two double-faults from Nishikori in game 12 cost him dearly, bringing Murray two break points. Much to the British star's fury, he tosses away the first one but is not so profligate with the next, keeping the ball in play in a long rally and pulling his opponent across the court before Nishikori nets. One hour on the clock, one set on the board for GB.
Goffin continues to hold serve without undue bother, however Cilic's most recent service game was a real struggle for the Croat, in keeping with the theme of the match...

Back to Hannover then where a fifth rubber will decide whether it's Germany or the Czech Republic who will go through to July's quarterfinals. Talented German teenager Alexander Zverev takes on Lukas Rosol. If you'd like to follow that match, then bring your Sunday lunch to our daviscup.tv live streaming sofa.

Nishikori breaks Murray at the start of the second set and backs it up with a hold having been taken to 30-30. The last two points in particular showed Nishikori at his best - dashing about the court with nimble footwork and putting Murray under pressure to come up with a winner.

A big forehand from Mikhail Kukushkin sees him win an epic ninth game which extended beyond 12 minutes. The Kazakh raises his arms aloft. He's one game away from nicking the second set from Novak Djokovic. The Kazakh trumpets are going wild! Meanwhile, Djokovic is holding an ice pack to his left thigh at the change of ends.

So Goffin's serve remains thoroughly impregnable and he duly takes a two-sets-to-love lead against Cilic, who remains somewhat ill at ease. One more set for Goffin will give us a final rubber decider in Liege.

Head to https://t.co/yWHYvRPzQs to download the #DavisCup dates for 2016 to your calendar so you never miss a moment pic.twitter.com/eP1M2e4eke

— Davis Cup (@DavisCup) March 6, 2016
Plenty of breaks of serve but nothing to separate Novak Djokovic and Mikhail Kukushkin in Serbia v Kazakhstan. So off we go to another tiebreak in Belgrade…

Murray breaks back in Birmingham. Nishikori's serve is never going to be any huge threat so if Murray can dominate the rallies he is sure to have plenty of joy, and that's pretty much what happens here, alongside some testing returns from the British no. 1.
It's been confirmed that Czech star Tomas Berdych retired from his match against Germany's Philipp Kohlschreiber because of a hamstring injury.

What does Kohlschreiber put his improved performance down to? "The speeches in the locker room. They told me, 'Everything is possible. Go out, be very aggressive, no matter who the player is on the court, and don't be the rabbit running around.' I managed that very well."

 

He also had some words on his young teammate, Sascha Zverev: "I am very positive right now. He is the kind of guy, and has the attitude, to take these kind of moments. I never saw him really nervous. He is very smooth. I am confident he will get the third point for Germany."

Do we spy a bit of Novak Djokovic swagger in Serbia? The world No.1 lures Mikhail Kukushkin into a series of errors for a 5-2 lead in the tiebreak. He brings up set point with a lovely drifted backhand which drops perfectly over the net. And an ace sees Djokovic serve out the breaker 73. One-set all in Belgrade.
Czech it out. Lukas Rosol makes his move in the opening set against Germany's Alexander Zverev, taking the early break. A long way to go yet, mind.

This is absolutely breathtaking stuff in Belgrade. Gasping for air as he supported himself with his racket when 4-3 down in the second set, Djokovic once again dug very deep to haul himself – and Serbia – back into the tie. Battling a barrage of stinging baseline shots from Kukushkin, the world No.1 forced a tiebreak and closed it out with an ace, clenching his fist in delight as the partisan home crowd roared him on.

 

We couldn't agree more Zoran. This match is great! Follow it on our livestream.

Enjoy your first match for the #SwissDavisCupTeam, @antoine_bellier! Let's go! #ITASUI #SupportTheSwiss pic.twitter.com/8viXrmrxCv

— Swiss Tennis (@swiss_tennis) March 6, 2016

Murray is being extended quite regularly by Nishikori and getting fairly agitated at times, with Leon Smith standing up on several occasions to try to impart some wisdom through telepathy. As for Dan Evans and Jamie Murray, they appear to be putting faith in divine providence.

Is it looking ominous for Germany's Davis Cup debutant Alexander Zverev? After a bright start, the 18-year-old pumps the ball long to hand two set points to Lukas Rosol. The first one sails past but Zverev nets to hands the Czechs the crucial first set.

blog.tle: Une Bonne Matinee pour Monsieur Le Coq!

blogs.blog: The official French mascot had every excuse to party last night after Yannick Noah's men had wrapped up their tie against Canada post-haste, but he's still turned up for the reverse singles in Guadeloupe in any event.

Some words from Tomas Berdych on the injury that forced him to withdraw midway through his match with Philipp Kohlschreiber: "It happened very early, I think it was the second or third game when I ran for a drop shot and then stretched for the passing shot and I felt pain in my right hamstring. The treatment helped for a while, but basically that was it. I knew it wasn't getting better and I couldn't play on the level that I wanted to. There was no chance I could finish the match."

Huge frustration for Alexander - better known as Sascha - Zverev in Germany as he is broken by Lukas Rosol right at the start of the second set. The teenager is being gently urged on by the German bench and the home crowd but he is looking rattled. No-one can blame him. A bit of a baptism of fire trying to save a Davis Cup tie for your nation on your debut weekend!

For the first time in the match, Goffin is forced to go and win points rather than wait for his opponent to make the errors. And Cilic steps it up a gear in a long sixth game to force pressure on the Goffin serve, before eventually securing the break at the end of an excellent rally.

Mikhail Kukushkin has showed no signs of slowing down after losing the second set to Novak Djokovic. The Kazakh has broken the world No.1 twice in the third for a 4-1 lead. Djokovic recovers one of them, breaking to love when Kukushkin nets. The see-saw momentum continues.

The Davis Cup classic between Djokovic and Kukushkin is being closely watched by reporters and volunteers alike inside Belgrade's Aleksandar Nikolic Arena. I can also report, the sandwiches on offer are almost as delicious as one of Kukushkin’s winners, which have had the away fans in raptures.
The Argentina team, led by captain Daniel Orsanic, celebrate reaching the last eight of the 2016 Davis Cup by BNP Paribas. Argentina have finished as runners-up four times.

A return from Andy Murray that would have Andre Agassi purring in appreciation brings up two set points. He gets involved in a long rally in the first of them, and Nishikori wins it with some fine tennis of his own. Next: a bad error from Murray, deuce. And two more errors from the British player mean we're into a tiebreak.

The news of Argentina's win in Poland will have come as no surprise but still as a delight to Italian captain Corrado Barazzutti, whose side cleaned up their tie against Switzerland in two days. Why so cheery? Because only an Argentina win could have guaranteed the Italians another home tie on clay. Having been unbeaten on Italian soil for seven years in Davis Cup ties, Barazzutti insists: "Playing at home is key."

 

He believes it could pave the way towards their first title since he played in their sole 1976 triumph. "We always must have dreams," Barazzutti told me with a smile last night. He's smiling even more now that Italy have gone 4-0 up with his debutant Marco Cecchinato beating Adrien Bossel 63 75.
Cilic secures the third set. He actually had chances in the eighth game, but Goffin temporarily rescued the situation before Cilic served it out solidly enough.

Novak Djokovic is going through the mill, and that's not something we can say very often. After sending over two double faults to concede another break, the world No.1 has broken back. But he is still a break down to Mikhail Kukushkin in the third set.

Since when did tennis crowds sound like football crowds? #tennis #DavisCup

— Mary Poppins (@xxmarypoppinsxx) March 6, 2016

blog.tle: Reflections from Belgium by DavisCup.com's Clive White

blogs.blog: Is this the start of the long climb back for Cilic? Certainly Goffin contributed greatly to losing the third set 63 with three double faults in the sixth game, the only game in which he has been broken since the start of the match. Clearly, Cilic's confidence is now up and Goffin's a little down. It's going to be fascinating here on in.

Novak Djokovic is having another go on the physio's magic towel at the change of ends. He has a rub down and then drapes an iced towel over his shoulders, before getting up to stretch his legs. The world No.1 clearly struggling but not giving up when it comes to levelling the tie for Serbia. Meanwhile, Mikhail Kukushkin is one game away from the third set.

Murray leads 4-0 in the tiebreak, but thumps a forehand into the net. Two serves for Nishikori now, what can he do? He wins them both, Murray failing to land either of his returns in bounds. Nishikori wins the next rally to make it 4-4, before the next two points are shared. Set point for Nishikori now as Murray floats one long. But back comes the dual Grand Slam champion, winning both his serves to go from 5-6 down to 7-6 ahead and when Nishikori tamely nets a groundstroke - in the middle of which Murray had produced an outstanding retrieve - the second set is finally in the bag for Great Britain.

So much drama happening all around the World Group. In Hannover, Lukas Rosol pumps the ball long on set point in the second. There's no mistake when a second opportunity comes. This time Rosol pumps his fist. The Czech Republic are one step closer to the last eight.

blog.tle: The moment of triumph for Leo Mayer

blogs.blog:
.@YacaMayer's heroics send Argentina into the @DavisCup QF. Read: https://t.co/tecNwlylSy #atp #tennis pic.twitter.com/FztZJ9Jnu4

— ATP World Tour (@ATPWorldTour) March 6, 2016

Kazakhstan are on the brink of reaching the last eight. A gripping third set finally goes the way of Mikhail Kukushin, who slices over a volley to seal the vital point. Novak Djokovic is battling in Belgrade but he faces a big struggle to keep Serbia alive now.

(Andy Murray having gone two sets to love up over Kei Nishikori...)


Looked like Andy Murray was about to throw the tiebreak away from a 4-0 lead but he saves a set point and then produces some terrific defence to take a two-set lead and put Great Britain just one set from the quarterfinals.


Towards the end of the set, Murray noticeably had a glance up towards the big screen which was showing the scores from the other ties, no doubt paying particular interest in Serbia vs Kazakhstan. If Britain go through, they face a home tie against the Kazakhs or an away trip to Serbia.

Playing a decisive fifth rubber in your first Davis Cup tie is quite the daunting task and it's been a difficult day so far for young Sascha Zverev. The 18-year-old trails Rosol by two sets to love and is struggling to find any sort of rhythm against the Czech No. 2, who likes to give the ball a good whack. The Czechs are one-set from a spot in the quarterfinals, but in a tie full of twists and turns we can't rule out the Germans just yet.

COME ON KUKUSHKIN 👍🏻 https://t.co/XBPVlxOktX

— Gemma-Lou ❤️ (@XxgemidodgerxX) March 6, 2016

Mikhail Kukushkin noses ahead again after winning the third set against Novak Djokovic, meaning that Kazakhstan are one set away from pulling off what would be a stunning upset in Belgrade. The players traded a flurry of breaks throughout the third set before Kukushkin held serve to close it out with a pair of sublime volleys. Looking tired and bereft of ideas, Djokovic will have to find the energy he is lacking at the moment if he is to keep Serbia's challenge alive.

 

And Kukushkin has just saved three break points in his opening game of the fourth set.

Hands on hips time for David Goffin after Marin Cilic, break point down, curls a forehand onto the line that's just out of reach for the Belgian. Three more break points come Goffin's way. He spurns the first two, but not the third. And the crowds really come to life when Cilic's slightly cramped backhand sails half a metre long.

Back to Hannover, where Alexander Zverev has been toiling against Lukas Rosol. The 18-year-old is highly rated as a rising star on the ATP Tour but the Davis Cup brings unique pressures. Rosol, the world No.50, may only have played 12 ties but the Czech team have bags of experience and desire. A couple of slapdash shots from Zverev see him broken again. The Czechs will surely be packing their bags for a home tie with France now.

Goffin serves for the match and is broken! Some fine returns from Cilic there, who played the last two points particularly well. We are suddenly a fair way from finding a winner of this rubber, let alone finding a winner of the tie - marvellous stuff.

The Czech team start their celebrations. Lukas Rosol cruises past Alexander Zverev 62 63 61 - winning the third set in just 26 minutes - to seal the tie for the Czech team, who congregate in the centre of the court for a jig of joy. Zverev, looks disconsolate, but will regroup as Germany head into the World Group play-offs in July. The Czechs host France in the quarterfinals.

Nishikori keeps Japan alive in the Davis Cup 2016! Murray has not been at his best and he's broken in the eighth game of the third set, chucking a double fault into the mix. Nishikori comes under some pressure as he serves for the set but comes through the test with a fine passing shot taking us into a fourth set in the fourth rubber in Birmingham.

Just the luck Novak Djokovic needed. The Serbian brings up break point and Mikhail Kukushkin attempts a drop shot but misses! Djokovic is now a break up in the fourth set and attempting to carve out a comeback to the delight of the Serbian home crowd. The volume has been raised in Belgrade, which is not music to Kukushkin's ears.

Cilic is beaten by Goffin in Liege! It's been an absorbing contest, not necessarily featuring tennis of the very highest quality, but Goffin has been much the more consistent of the two. When Cilic finds himself 5-6, 15-40 he saves the first match point with a big strong serve but then there's a double fault and Goffin raises both arms aloft! He wins 64 64 36 75.

Well done 👏👏👏 https://t.co/DYeDDCImp7

— TomášBerdychFans (@TBerdychFans) March 6, 2016

blog.tle: This is what Davis Cup defeat looks like

blogs.blog: Alexander Zverev cuts a forlorn figure after losing the decisive fifth rubber against Lukas Rosol in Germany.

Now here is some record Murray is protecting, as spotted by our man Stuart Fraser in Birmingham: "The British fans should not worry too much just yet. Andy Murray is an impressive 133-1 from two sets up in his career - his only defeat from that position was at the age of 18 against David Nalbandian at Wimbledon in 2005."

Novak Djokovic rocks back his head and roars in delight. We are going the distance in Serbia after four hours and 18 minutes. Djokovic has just won the fourth set against Mikhail Kukushkin to keep the tie alive for Serbia. On we go…

The 19-year-old world no.47 Borna Coric will be the last card played by Croatian captain Zeljko Crajan as this keenly contested tie goes to the final rubber. He'll be up against Kimmer Coppejans, the junior champion at Roland Garros in 2012 who hasn't made the adjustment to the senior circuit quite so successfully. This could be his moment, however.
Jelena Djokovic allows herself a smile on the sidelines as her husband levels the tie for Serbia. Another fan ups the celebrations by tooting on a plastic trumpet. That's so very Davis Cup.

Novak Djokovic finds another gear to win the fourth set 63 and level his contest with Mikhail Kukushkin at two sets all, setting up an enthralling climax to this already electrifying contest in Belgrade. Serbia are banking on the world No.1 to prevail and level the tie at 2-2 before home crowd favourite Viktor Troicki faces either Andrey Golubev or Aleksandr Nedovyesov in the final rubber.

The momentum is with Novak Djokovic now. Mikhail Kukushkin lashes the ball wild and long to hand the world No.1 the break in the opening game of the first set. Is that the turning point of this crackerjack match?

Brilliant stuff from Nishikori after some sloppy tennis from Murray. The Japanese player dominates a crucial point when given a glimpse and breaks Murray for a potentially crucial 3-2 lead in the fourth set. Nishikori is being Nishikori, playing top-level consistently strong tennis. Unless Murray gets back to the level he was at the start of the match things could turn sour for both him and GB.

Italy have just wrapped up their 5-0 whitewash here, with Paolo Lorenzi beating Swiss teenage debutant Antoine Bellier 63 62. The emphatic defeat once again illustrates just how much the Swiss rely on their dynamic duo of Roger Federer and Stan Wawrinka - but will they be back to help rescue their World Group status for next season? Captain Severin Luthi wishes he knew the answer himself. 

 

"For sure, there's a chance that the two of them will be back in September," shrugged Fed's old pal Luthi, who was grateful to have them both back for last year's equivalent tie which saw the Swiss beat the Netherlands in just two days. "But it depends on the draw and there's got to be three more Grand Slam tournaments, plus the Olympics too, before our next tie so there’s a lot of tennis down the road before we see what’s going to happen."
Paulo Lorenzi completes the whitewash for Italy to the delight of the home fans. Grazie!

Nishikori is set to serve for the fourth set and continue his recovery from two sets to love down against Murray. Both players appear to be fully energised so there's every chance that we could get an enthralling final set assuming Nishikori does not fluff his lines after the changeover.
Goffin completes his second singles rubber win of the weekend... now it's up to Kimmer Coppejans to complete the job for last year's runners-up Belgium.

Austria are through to the second round of the Europe/Africa Group I thanks to a 3-1 win over hosts Portugal. Dominic Thiem with a vital 62 64 62 win over Joao Sousa on Sunday. Austria will play Ukraine, who received a bye, for a place in the World Group play-offs in July.

So, with Dan Evans and Taro Daniel waiting in the wings if required, Murray is taken into a final set by his tenacious Japanese opponent. Murray does manage to save one break point but is outrallied immediately afterwards.


Total games won (counting the tiebreak as a single game) so far: Murray 21-23 Nishikori, and here's Stuart Fraser: "Murray looks to have lost his intensity, perhaps a result of playing three consecutive days after going almost five weeks without a match before this weekend."

Novak Djokovic is Serbia's saviour once more. The world No.1 fights back from two sets to one down, and a physical slump, to record a 67(6) 76(3) 46 63 62 win over Mikhail Kukushkin. The Kazakh really pushed Djokovic and can definitely feel proud of his performance. By the way, the whole shebang took just shy of five hours. Djokovic never knows when to give up and that's why he's the world No.1.

 

The tie? Well that will be decided by a fifth rubber. Stay tuned!

Novak Djokovic...what a champion. It's one thing to dominate when you're playing well but to dig this match out when ill, playing poorly...

— Randy Walker (@TennisPublisher) March 6, 2016

Oh this is pretty worrying for GB and their home supporters and pretty wonderful for the travelling patrons from Japan. Murray is broken at the very start of the fifth set: not enough going on with his serve as Nishikori slams a good return into the far corner, and follows up with a winning drive volley.
Back comes Murray with a vengeance - breaks Nishikori to love!

Berdych was due to fly straight to Indian Wells from Hannover. He'll now travel to Prague first to have his hamstring injury assessed there.

— Leigh Walsh (@LeighWalsh87) March 6, 2016

blog.tle: Who do you fancy in this titanic tussle?

blogs.blog:
Even though Nishikori looks like he's just walked on court, and Murray looks like his legs are made of concrete, fancy Muzza. #DavisCup

— Miles Evans (@milominder) March 6, 2016

An evenly split opening six games in the big deciding rubber in Liege. There would have been fears that Coppejans would struggle to deal with the youthful and seriously talented Coric, but at the moment he is holding his own. We could have a very late finish here.

Nishikori has suddenly gone to pieces, making three critical errors in his second service game of the final set. Now will Murray let him off the hook again? He certainly will have no intention of doing that...

It's all with serve late in the first set of the Coppejans-Coric match, the rubber that will decide whether hosts Belgium or visiting nation Croatia will advance to the quarterfinals. These fans have every faith in their man Coppejans.

blog.tle: What's happening in Europe/Africa Group I?

blogs.blog:
For those who are following the Group I Europe/Africa Zone action, here's how the teams will line up in July's second round. 

 

Spain v Romania
Ukraine v Austria
Russia v Netherlands
Hungary v Slovakia

 

The first round of relegation play-offs will be played in September.
To the enormous frustration of the Great Britain fans, Murray tosses away another service game to relinquish the advantage he had built. There's been only one service hold in this set so far.

I lived on so many different time zones this weekend... But it was worth it ! Thanks @DavisCup it was a great one !! #DavisCup

— David Morin (@DavidMorinV) March 6, 2016

Viktor Troicki is getting proceedings under way again in Belgrade, where the crowd don't seem to have cooled off at all after Novak Djokovic's five-set win. Troicki is facing Aleksandr Nedovyesov as he aims to book Serbia's place in the quarterfinals. You can follow the action on the daviscup.tv live streaming sofa, where we welcome all manner of chocolate biscuits, especially this deep into a Davis Cup weekend.
Watch the triumphant team make an entrance as they come to face the media in Poland.

The quality in this match appears to be draining away, until Nishikori plays some outstanding tennis from double break-point down. After a couple of deuces, Murray gets another break-point - and this time he pummels his return down the line - no way Nishikori is chasing that one down.

Bosnia Herzegovina book their place in July's second round in the World Group II Europe/Africa Zone with a 3-1 win over Tunisia. Mirza Basic came through an epic five-setter against Malek Jaziri, winning the fourth-set tiebreak 18-16. Well done. We'll give you the full line-up of the second-round ties soon!

.@DavisCup is the greatest thing ever... especially when you come back from 0-2 & save 5 match points on the way! #BiH 🇧🇦 #DavisCup

— Amer Delic (@AmerDelic) March 6, 2016

Kimmer Coppejans has been playing admirably in the Liege decider but he has just lost the first set. A really close tiebreak went to 5-5 before Coppejans hit a forehand slightly long and slightly wide. That gave Coric the opportunity to pounce and the Croat won the following rally to wrap up a lengthy first set.

Let's head back to Belgrade, where Viktor Troicki has just broken Aleksandr Nedovyesov. The Kazakh couldn't quite bumble the ball back over the net after a lucky net cord for the Serbian. Troicki saved a break point against him early on, and this match has been close so far. Early days but advantage Serbia.

All of a sudden, we are at the end game in Birmingham. Nishikori is double matchpoint down, and Murray gets a look at a second serve. The serve lands on the line however, and Murray can't get it back. There's a thrilling rally through the next point, but it's Nishikori who wins it, so we're at deuce. Nishikori hangs really tough through the next four points, winning three of them, and now Murray will have to serve it out to claim the tie.

Murray gets to 30-0 with a big, unreturnable first serve. Then there's a simply extraordinary rally, both players drawing on the last dregs of energy they must have - and Murray wins it - he has three more match points. Nishikori finds a sublime winning return for 40-15, but Murray's big first serve from the following point finally sets up a winning maneouvre. Wow, what a match - nearly five hours of thoroughly absorbing tennis. Murray wins it 75 76(6) 36 46 63.

"It was an important match, I've never played when it was 2-2, so this was a special feeling for me as well. I've played more matches than Alex (Zverev) and that helped me. 

 

"We are trying to go tie after tie. We have a great team and we are looking forward to the next tie against France."

Quick work in Belgrade as Viktor Troicki races to the opener in just 26 minutes against Kazakh Aleksandr Nedovyesov. Great Britain have just booked their placed in the quarterfinals. If Serbia win this match and tie then they will host the defending champs next.

blog.tle: Murray draws on 'positive energy' to win

blogs.blog:
Andy Murray: "The crowd helped for sure. I was trying to keep the points short in the third and fourth sets, but it didn't work and in the fifth set I managed to grit my teeth and get it done. Thankfully I managed to get through and I don't think we are going to play a dead rubber today, I think everyone's seen enough tennis and we can go home and rest.

 

"I was a little bit calmer in the first set. I had been gettinng very frustrated at the end of the third set but in the fifth I went back to what I was doing at the start, to get myself pumped up with positive energy.


"Last year's experience was incredible for everyone on the team. We did something special last year and I would like to try do something similar this year."

What a match What fabulous tennis What amazing athletes on both sides of the net Congratulations Team GB! #daviscup https://t.co/mfZAUYtB7m

— Stephen Taylor (@STaylor_67) March 6, 2016

What a herculean effort by Andy Murray, as we have come to expect from him in Davis Cup. At four hours and 54 minutes, that is the joint-longest match of his career with the 2012 US Open final against Novak Djokovic, which he also won.


No time for celebrations in Birmingham tonight though, as Murray will head straight back to his home near London to enjoy the rest of Mother’s Day with wife Kim and their four-week old daughter Sophia.
By winning his 14th Davis Cup match (singles and doubles) in succession, Andy Murray has broken Fred Perry's British record.

The Serbian crowd are on their feet. They've had their money's worth in Belgrade, no doubt about that. Viktor Troicki conjures a fabulous passing shot to break Aleksandr Nedovyesov in the second set. It's looking good now for Serbia's quarterfinal hopes.

These Davis Cup matches with Andy involved are just priceless sagas aren't they? Truly incredible really. Onto the next. #DavisCup

— Nick Metcalfe (@Nick_Metcalfe) March 6, 2016
World No.1 Novak Djokovic is the hero for Serbia once more after swashbuckling his way through a five-set win.

Fans of Europe/Africa Zone Group II, you might want to note these fixtures in your diary for 15-17 July. These fixtures will determine who goes through to round three.

 

Lithuania v South Africa
Turkey v Bosnia/Herzegovina
Latvia v Belarus
Finland v Denmark

 

The relegation play-offs also take place in July.

It looks like Borna Coric, in only his second Davis Cup tie, is on the point of bringing home the bacon for Croatia and setting up a trip to the USA in July's quarterfinals. He motors through the second set, sealing it with a lovely serve-volley that is reminiscent of Boris Becker at his finest.

It's a second break for Viktor Troicki in Serbia. Aleksandr Nedovyesov slams the ball into the net to concede the break at 5-1. But Troicki, the world No.23, is broken in the very next game, which was a bit slapdash. The Serbian still has the upper hand though.

blog.tle: Click play to listen to Czech star Lukas Rosol
The champions are through to the last eight

blogs.blog: ...and doesn't that mean the world to Andy Murray, who has a new British record 14th consecutive Davis Cup win to celebrate for good measure...
READ ALL ABOUT IT! Our news index has all the stories from a tumultous final day of action from the Davis Cup by BNP Paribas.

Serbia are just one set away now from a quarterfinal meeting with Great Britain. Aleksandr Nedovyesov has been trying a new tactic of getting into the net but Viktor Troicki is just too fast and fierce for the Kazakh. He claims the second set in 38 minutes, winning 90% of his points on first serve.

Unfortunate to retire my match today, but well done team and Lukas for the win!! 🇨🇿🇨🇿🇨🇿

— Tomáš Berdych (@tomasberdych) March 6, 2016

Kimmer Coppejans is doing his best to keep the ship afloat for last year's runners-up Belgium, but time is running out and he's up against a very good young player who's looking very good at the moment. It appears David Goffin's heroics may well be in vain.

Coric banks on his athleticism to run down a drop shot and send it back over the net for a winner before sealing Croatia's passage to the quarterfinals with an ace. That's what you call emphatic. A game attempt by Coppejans to make a match of it, especially in the early sets, but Coric was on it today - and he wins 76(5) 62 62.
Break point chances for both players in Belgrade, but once again it's Viktor Troicki who makes his count, forcing Aleksandr Nedovyesov to net with powerful forehand. Troicki is on a roll.

I'm going to have to go to more tennis after today's #DavisCup win. @andy_murray was immense pic.twitter.com/DK5FfKyDcK

— Bendy (@bendy) March 6, 2016

Croatia are through to the quarterfinals and deservedly so. Inevitably it's a low-key victory, not just because the tie is in Belgium but because after David Goffin's heroics this weekend the Belgians understandably felt they deserved better. In the end Borna Coric, although three years younger than his opponent Kimmer Coppejans at just 19, was just a little too steady for him, winning 76(5) 62 62. Belgium, however, can take heart from their performance against a team who may very well end up winning this competition.

Viktor Troicki is keeping things tidy in Belgrade. He is just two game away from victory - and from settling the Davis Cup by BNP Paribas World Group quarterfinal line-up. Aleksandr Nedovyesov is refusing to go quietly, and who can blame him after a really strong performance by Kazakhstan this weekend. If only the world No.1 wasn't on the other side of the net earlier eh?…

Troicki is kept up to task as he serves for the tie, even having to stave off a couple of break points, but he does come up with the goods to win the rubber 62 63 64 in an hour and 51 minutes. Nedovyesov has battle valiantly through the week, contributing to the doubles point won by Kazakhstan, but he was second best today. And finally, a tie that began after lunch on Friday is concluded on a Sunday night. Serbia will host defending champions Great Britain in July's quarterfinals, so guess what? That could mean Djokovic v Murray...

blog.tle: Pietrangeli (won a record 120 Davis Cup rubbers) in Pesaro

blogs.blog:
History of Tennis today at @DavisCup Nicola Pietrangeli and Lea Pericoli with @AdeccoItalia @AdeccoGroup #DavisCup pic.twitter.com/gfb96xchvJ

— Verena Godani (@verenagodani) March 6, 2016

blog.tle: Sunday: World Group in a nutshell

blogs.blog:
After France and Italy had secured their quarterfinal berths by gaining unassailable 3-0 leads on Saturday, the five remaining Davis Cup quarterfinalists were decided today.


First, John Isner gave USA the winning point in Australia before the focus switched to Europe. Andy Murray was stretched to five sets by Kei Nishikori before holders GB beat Japan and Argentina won in Poland thanks to Leonardo Mayer.


The remaining three ties all went to final-rubber deciders: Czech Republic, Serbia and Croatia the successful nations with Lukas Rosol, Viktor Troicki and Borna Coric supplying the vital wins.
Watch the best bits of Leonardo Mayer's four-set win over Michal Przysiezny which secured Argentina's trip to Italy for the quarterfinals coming up this summer.

An update from Americas Zone Group II, where, thanks to a success in the first Sunday singles by Marcelo Arevalo, El Salvador have beaten Puerto Rico 3-1. They join Mexico and Venezuela as victors from that section. Peru are currently involved in a deciding rubber with Uruguay in Miraflores, Lima.

France, having done the important stuff by the end of Saturday, enjoyed a relaxing day in Guadeloupe where the fans nevertheless poured in for the final day of action. Richard Gasquet made it 4-0 against Canada before Frank Dancevic was forced to retire having taken the first set against Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

blog.tle: SHOT OF THE DAY: David Goffin

blogs.blog: Artistry, athleticism and sheer brilliance of technique: it's all there in this winning shot by Belgium's David Goffin against Croatia's Marin Cilic today.

First named team plays at home, number denotes Davis Cup seeding prior to this weekend's action

Serbia (7) v GB (1)
Italy (9) v Argentina (6)
France (5) v Czech Republic (2)
USA (11) v Croatia (16)

Serbia needed to win both Sunday's singles to beat Kazakhstan and reach the quarterfinals. Novak Djokovic needed five sets to win his match, Viktor Troicki just three to win his.


Troicki said: "It may have looked easy as I won in straight sets, but it wasn’t. I have to congratulate Novak first for a heroic effort. He definitely deserves all the credit and I am glad that I played my part."

blog.tle: Note how the sidespin on Murray's defensive forehand deceives Nishikori...

blogs.blog:
Relive the moment @andy_murray sent Great Britain into the 2016 #DavisCup quarterfinals #BackTheBritshttps://t.co/Rh7DeyDmvR

— Davis Cup (@DavisCup) March 6, 2016

blog.tle: Thanks for joining us, see you again in July

blogs.blog: ...or simply tune in to our Fed Cup live blogs, streams, reports, stats and features at http://www.fedcup.com/en/home.aspx from 15 April. We hope you enjoyed our Davis Cup by BNP Paribas coverage.
